elements.content: The one-pot reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O and 5-(6-(hydroxymethyl)­pyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2 L) in DMF/H2O (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) produced a two-dimensional (2D) metal–organic framework (MOF) of [Cd­(L)­(H2O)2] (A) bearing aqua-bridged Cd centers, accompanied by two three-dimensional (3D) MOFs [Cd­(L)­(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd­(L)] (C). Removing the bridging aqua molecules of A by heating led to the formation of an additional 3D MOF of [Cd­(L)] (D) in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) manner. The search for the preceding compound that could convert to A resulted in the isolation of a 2D MOF [Cd­(L)­(DMF)] (E) that readily converted to A in water, but with the loss of single crystallinity. Upon excitation at 350 nm, A, D, E, and the ligand H2 L fluoresced at 460 nm, 468 nm, 475 nm, and 411 nm, respectively. The fluorescence of A could be used for the selective detection of Fe3+ in water down to 0.58 ppm. This quenching was not affected by the presence of other common metal ions.

Removing the bridging aqua molecules of A by heating led to the formation of an additional 3D MOF of [Cd(L)] (D) in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) manner. Upon excitation at 350 nm, A, D, E, and the ligand H2 L fluoresced at 460 nm, 468 nm, 475 nm, and 411 nm, respectively. The fluorescence of A could be used for the selective detection of Fe3+ in water down to 0.58 ppm. This quenching was not affected by the presence of other common metal ions.

elements.content:
Structural relationships among a class of five Cd-based MOFs are elucidated, and one of these compounds is highly emissive and able to selectively detect Fe3+.

Introduction

Since the milestone reports of (i) the topological analysis of Cu­[C­(C6H4CN)]­(BF4) by Robson et al., (ii) the gas storage of [M2(4,4′-bpy)3­(NO3)4] (M = Co, Ni, Zn) by Kitagawa et al., and (iii) [Zn4O­(BDC)3] (MOF-5) by Yaghi et al., metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have captured the imagination of both chemists and materials scientists. This interest stems from the challenge of creating more beautiful MOF structures and their utilization as host materials for gases, drugs, catalysts, and proteins, as well as their electronic and sensing properties, and further conversion of these molecular scaffolds into useful nanomaterials. One of the key concerns that hinders the utility of MOF materials is their phase purity, which is intrinsically linked to a variety of parameters during preparation, such as the reagent (including solvent) purity, concentration, temperature, and modulators. The ongoing interest in iconic MOF-5, for example, has helped to elucidate various factors that contribute to the product outcome and subsequent material performance. The species identified during the synthesis of MOF-5 type materials include [Zn3(OH)2­(BDC)2­(DEF)2], ZnO nanoparticles, trapped mononuclear [Zn­(OH)2­(H2O)2], and a partially interpenetrated isomorph. Grzesiak et al. also demonstrated that, in the presence of insoluble polymer substrates, similar reaction as the preparation of MOF-5 produced [Zn3(BDC)3­(DEF)2] (DEF = N,N-diethylformamide). More recently, the dynamic coordination of DMF solvate to the Zn4O cluster in MOF-5 has been reported. Chiral inducing reagent l- or d-proline facilitates the formation of Λ-MOF-5 or Δ-MOF-5, respectively.

Introduction

Since the milestone reports of (i) the topological analysis of Cu[C(C6H4CN)](BF4) by Robson et al., (ii) the gas storage of [M2(4,4'-bpy)3(NO3)4] (M = Co, Ni, Zn) by Kitagawa et al., and (iii) [Zn4O(BDC)3] (MOF-5) by Yaghi et al., metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have captured the imagination of both chemists and materials scientists. This interest stems from the challenge of creating more beautiful MOF structures and their utilization as host materials for gases, drugs, catalysts, and proteins, as well as their electronic and sensing properties, and further conversion of these molecular scaffolds into useful nanomaterials. One of the key concerns that hinders the utility of MOF materials is their phase purity, which is intrinsically linked to a variety of parameters during preparation, such as the reagent (including solvent) purity, concentration, temperature, and modulators. The ongoing interest in iconic MOF-5, for example, has helped to elucidate various factors that contribute to the product outcome and subsequent material performance. The species identified during the synthesis of MOF-5 type materials include [Zn3(OH)2(BDC)2(DEF)2], ZnO nanoparticles, trapped mononuclear [Zn(OH)2(H2O)2], and a partially interpenetrated isomorph. Grzesiak et al. also demonstrated that, in the presence of insoluble polymer substrates, similar reaction as the preparation of MOF-5 produced [Zn3(BDC)3(DEF)2] (DEF = N,N-diethylformamide). More recently, the dynamic coordination of DMF solvate to the Zn4O cluster in MOF-5 has been reported. Chiral inducing reagent l- or d-proline facilitates the formation of Λ-MOF-5 or Δ-MOF-5, respectively.

elements.content: Identifying product relationships in the synthesis of MOFs could permit exquisite control of the product outcome and reduce the formation of impurities. Elucidating these relationships is challenging, however, because many products are precipitated as insoluble polymeric residues which hinder effective separation. A plethora of single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) conversions have been achieved and provide useful insights into the relationships between MOF sublattices. Extending this strategy to multiple, sequential SCSC transformations would be an exciting development in the quest for rational MOF design.

elements.content: In this article, we describe a one-pot assembly of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 5-(6-(hydroxymethyl)­pyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2 L) in DMF/H2O to afford a two-dimensional (2D) MOF [Cd­(L)­(H2O)2] (A) and two three-dimensional (3D) MOFs [Cd­(L)­(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd­(L)] (C). MOF A consists of a Cd2 unit connected by a pair of aqua bridges. A trial of SCSC conversion by removing the aqua bridges in A, results in a new 3D MOF of [Cd­(L)] (D), which is a polymorph of C. Investigating the preceding complex that can convert to A in water led us to isolate a 2D MOF [Cd­(L)­(DMF)] (E), prepared via the reaction of Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O and H2 L in DMF. Single crystals of E convert to A within a period of ca. 2 h, but with the loss of single crystallinity. Compounds A, D, and E are luminescent and A selectively detects Fe3+ in water at ppm levels in the presence of other cations.

MOF A consists of a Cd2 unit connected by a pair of aqua bridges. A trial of SCSC conversion by removing the aqua bridges in A, results in a new 3D MOF of [Cd(L)] (D), which is a polymorph of C. Investigating the preceding complex that can convert to A in water led us to isolate a 2D MOF [Cd(L)(DMF)] (E), prepared via the reaction of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and H2 L in DMF. Single crystals of E convert to A within a period of ca. 2 h, but with the loss of single crystallinity. Compounds A, D, and E are luminescent and A selectively detects Fe3+ in water at ppm levels in the presence of other cations.

elements.content: All reagents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. IR spectra were measured on a Varian 1000 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr disks (4000–400 cm–1). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were recorded on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C min–1) under an air atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were obtained on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Fluorescence spectra were acquired on a PTI Fluorescence Master System. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo-Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα X-ray radiation as the X-ray source for excitation. Binding energies were referenced to C 1s at 284.7 eV from hydrocarbon to compensate charging effects. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping experiments were performed on an FEI Tecnai F20 (USA) electron microscope operated at 200 kV and equipped with a Genesis EDS detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All reagents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. IR spectra were measured on a Varian 1000 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr disks (4000-400 cm-1). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were recorded on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C min-1) under an air atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were obtained on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). Fluorescence spectra were acquired on a PTI Fluorescence Master System. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo-Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα X-ray radiation as the X-ray source for excitation. Binding energies were referenced to C 1s at 284.7 eV from hydrocarbon to compensate charging effects. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping experiments were performed on an FEI Tecnai F20 (USA) electron microscope operated at 200 kV and equipped with a Genesis EDS detector.

elements.content: Method 1 (direct synthesis): Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (15.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) was mixed with H2 L (27 mg, 0.1 mmol) and DMF/H2O (5 mL/5 mL) in a 15 mL pressure tube. The reaction was heated to 120 °C in an oven for 72 h and cooled to room temperature over 48 h to give colorless block crystals. The formation of A was accompanied by the formation of [Cd­(L)­(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd­(L)] (C).

elements.content:
Aliquots of aqueous Fe3+ salts was sequentially added to a suspension of 2 mg A in 2 mL water in a 1 cm × 1 cm quartz cell equipped with a stirring bar and the fluorescence measured.

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of A, B, C, D, and E were analyzed on a Bruker D8 Quest CCD X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Refinement and reduction of the collected data were achieved by the program Bruker SAINT and applied to all complexes with absorption correction (multiscan). All crystal structures were solved by direct method and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXTL-2013. The hydrogen atoms on the bridging H2O molecules in A were added by HFIX 23 followed by restraining of their O–H distances to O–H = 0.83 Å with thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). The coordinates of the two hydrogen atoms on the dissociated water were suggested by the Calc-OH program in WinGX suite; the water molecule was then refined as a rigid model with the thermal parameters for H atoms constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). The H atom on alcoholic O was added by HFIX 43 with the O–H distance constrained to 0.83 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). For B, the L ligand displayed positional disorder with the relative ratio of 0.74/0.26 refined for the two disordered components. The occupancy factor for the solvate DMF was fixed at 0.5 to obtain reasonable thermal factors. The H atom on alcoholic O was added by HFIX 43 with the O–H distance constrained to 0.83 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). For C, the coordinates of the hydrogen atom on the alcoholic O were suggested by the Calc-OH program in WinGX suite, and the OH was subsequently refined as a rigid group with the thermal parameter for H atoms constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). For D, the hydrogen atom on the alcoholic O atom was added by HFIX 43 and its coordinates subsequently refined with the O–H distance fixed at 0.83 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). The hydrogen atom on the O–H group of E was located from the difference Fourier map with the O–H distance restrained to O–H = 0.83 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). A summary of key crystallographic information for A, B, C, D, and E is given in .

The reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with H2 L (1:2) in a 15 mL pressure tube with DMF/H2O (5 mL/5 mL) under solvothermal conditions gave rise to a mixture of colorless block crystals accompanied by light-yellow crystals and some tiny colorless crystals. These crystals corresponded to a 2D MOF of [Cd­(L)­(H2O)2] (A) and two 3D MOFs of [Cd­(L)­(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd­(L)] (C), as identified by single-crystal X-ray crystallography (). A PXRD spectrum of the bulk sample (Figure S1) did not match any of the simulated diffraction patterns, indicating phase impurity. We further checked the cell parameters for a series of randomly picked crystals from the mixture and found no evidence for the presence of additional compounds. The two Cd centers in A are bridged by a pair of aqua ligands, creating a short Cd···Cd separation of 3.814 Å (). This led us to make two predictions: (i) we should be able to acquire a preceding complex that can convert to A in water, and (ii) because the separation between the two Cd­(II) centers and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen from adjacent chains is short (Cd···O, 4.020–4.487 Å) (Table S1), the removal of the aqua bridges would trigger structure conversion in an SCSC manner.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Transformation

The reaction of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with H2 L (1:2) in a 15 mL pressure tube with DMF/H2O (5 mL/5 mL) under solvothermal conditions gave rise to a mixture of colorless block crystals accompanied by light-yellow crystals and some tiny colorless crystals. These crystals corresponded to a 2D MOF of [Cd(L)(H2O)2] (A) and two 3D MOFs of [Cd(L)(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd(L)] (C), as identified by single-crystal X-ray crystallography (). A PXRD spectrum of the bulk sample (Figure S1) did not match any of the simulated diffraction patterns, indicating phase impurity. We further checked the cell parameters for a series of randomly picked crystals from the mixture and found no evidence for the presence of additional compounds. The two Cd centers in A are bridged by a pair of aqua ligands, creating a short Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation of 3.814 Å (). This led us to make two predictions: (i) we should be able to acquire a preceding complex that can convert to A in water, and (ii) because the separation between the two Cd(II) centers and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen from adjacent chains is short (Cd⋅⋅⋅O, 4.020-4.487 Å) (Table S1), the removal of the aqua bridges would trigger structure conversion in an SCSC manner.

elements.content: To test our first postulate, we changed the reaction conditions by reducing the H2O content of the solvent. When the ratio of DMF/H2O was changed to 3:2, 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1, we observed similar mixture compositions as for the initial preparation of A (mixed with B and C). However, when we carried out the reaction in pure DMF, we obtained a 2D MOF [Cd­(L)­(DMF)] (E) ().
elements.clean_text: To test our first postulate, we changed the reaction conditions by reducing the H2O content of the solvent. When the ratio of DMF/H2O was changed to 3:2, 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1, we observed similar mixture compositions as for the initial preparation of A (mixed with B and C). However, when we carried out the reaction in pure DMF, we obtained a 2D MOF [Cd(L)(DMF)] (E) ().

elements.content: Immersing E in H2O did indeed lead to the formation of A after ca. 30 min, including maintenance of the shape of the crystal, but with the loss of diffraction. Prior to this period, the diffraction pattern resembled that of E. This is, with hindsight, understandable because the transformation of E into A is an interlayer process that requires drastic atom rearrangement in the solid state as well as the rotation of the L ligand. A time-dependent PXRD analysis (Figure S2) indicated that the conversion was complete within 2 h without the presence of additional phases, and at this stage, the single crystals became powdery. PXRD analysis of the powdery sample showed good agreement with the simulated spectrum of A (), indicative of quantitative conversion.

A time-dependent PXRD analysis (Figure S2) indicated that the conversion was complete within 2 h without the presence of additional phases, and at this stage, the single crystals became powdery. PXRD analysis of the powdery sample showed good agreement with the simulated spectrum of A (), indicative of quantitative conversion.

elements.content: To test our second assumption, we first analyzed the thermal gravimetric (TG) data of compound A to optimize the conversion temperature. As shown in Figure S3, the TG data of A (converted from E) indicated that the free and coordinated H2O molecules were removed at 100 °C. This weight loss is followed by a plateau until 250 °C, after which point the main framework started to decompose. Therefore, to obtain an SCSC conversion profile, single crystals of A (from a mixture of A, B, and C prepared in DMF/H2O solution) were heated at 110 °C for about 5 h. Surprisingly, we obtained a 3D structure D identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, and the conversion was verified by repeating the dehydration and analyzing with PXRD using pure A (converted from E, ).
elements.clean_text: To test our second assumption, we first analyzed the thermal gravimetric (TG) data of compound A to optimize the conversion temperature. As shown in Figure S3, the TG data of A (converted from E) indicated that the free and coordinated H2O molecules were removed at 100 °C. This weight loss is followed by a plateau until 250 °C, after which point the main framework started to decompose. Therefore, to obtain an SCSC conversion profile, single crystals of A (from a mixture of A, B, and C prepared in DMF/H2O solution) were heated at 110 °C for about 5 h. Surprisingly, we obtained a 3D structure D identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, and the conversion was verified by repeating the dehydration and analyzing with PXRD using pure A (converted from E, ).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound A has a 2D scale-like structure featuring a Cd2 L 2 macrocycle as the constructing “leaf” (Figure S5a). The shape of this Cd2 L 2 macrocycle approximates a parallelogram, and within each macrocycle, the two Cd centers are linked by a pair of chelating pyridine alcohols and a pair of chelating carboxylates in a head-to-tail fashion. The pair of carboxylates left is coordinated to two adjacent and equivalent Cd2 L 2 macrocycles in a complementary fashion and propagate the structure along the b direction. Each Cd center is thus associated with a chelating carboxylate, a chelating pyridine alcohol, a pair of μ-H2O, and one monodentate carboxylate to give a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure S5b). Each Cd2 L 2 macrocycle further extends to two equivalent macrocycles through two pairs of aqua bridges, propagating the structure along the c direction, and ultimately creating a 2D network extended within the bc plane ().

Solid-State Structure of Compound A 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound A has a 2D scale-like structure featuring a Cd2 L 2 macrocycle as the constructing "leaf" (Figure S5a). The shape of this Cd2 L 2 macrocycle approximates a parallelogram, and within each macrocycle, the two Cd centers are linked by a pair of chelating pyridine alcohols and a pair of chelating carboxylates in a head-to-tail fashion. The pair of carboxylates left is coordinated to two adjacent and equivalent Cd2 L 2 macrocycles in a complementary fashion and propagate the structure along the b direction. Each Cd center is thus associated with a chelating carboxylate, a chelating pyridine alcohol, a pair of μ-H2O, and one monodentate carboxylate to give a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure S5b). Each Cd2 L 2 macrocycle further extends to two equivalent macrocycles through two pairs of aqua bridges, propagating the structure along the c direction, and ultimately creating a 2D network extended within the bc plane ().

elements.content: The dimeric Cd2 L 2 unit and macrocyclic structure are also present in B. Each Cd center also adopts a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with a chelating carboxylate and a chelating pyridine alcohol. Contrasting A with each Cd center further associated with a pair of μ-H2O ligands and a monodentate carboxylate, the Cd center is further associated with a pair of μ-carboxylates and one DMF (a). The structure of B can be understood as a 3D network supported by one-dimensional (1D) chains wherein each chain connects four adjacent chains in two orthogonal directions (a,b). The Cd2 L 2 macrocycle within the 1D chain propagates along the a direction through the μ-carboxylate pairs. A pair of remaining carboxylates from the macrocycle serve as two μ-carboxylates for two adjacent chains, while the carboxylate and pyridine alcohol groups of the μ-carboxylate bridge support Cd2 L 2 macrocycles of the two orthogonal chains.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Structure of Compound B 

The dimeric Cd2 L 2 unit and macrocyclic structure are also present in B. Each Cd center also adopts a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with a chelating carboxylate and a chelating pyridine alcohol. Contrasting A with each Cd center further associated with a pair of μ-H2O ligands and a monodentate carboxylate, the Cd center is further associated with a pair of μ-carboxylates and one DMF (a). The structure of B can be understood as a 3D network supported by one-dimensional (1D) chains wherein each chain connects four adjacent chains in two orthogonal directions (a,b). The Cd2 L 2 macrocycle within the 1D chain propagates along the a direction through the μ-carboxylate pairs. A pair of remaining carboxylates from the macrocycle serve as two μ-carboxylates for two adjacent chains, while the carboxylate and pyridine alcohol groups of the μ-carboxylate bridge support Cd2 L 2 macrocycles of the two orthogonal chains.

elements.content: The structure of C also features a 3D network supported by 1D chains. The Cd2 L 2 macrocyclic subunit in C is also present, but has a different shape relative to those found in A and B. This Cd2 L 2 macrocyclic subunit is formed by a pair of L ligands (a), one using chelating pyridine alcohol and carboxylate, while the other using a chelating carboxylate and the second carboxylate in a μ3-η1:η2 coordination mode (b). This μ3-η1:η2 coordination juxtaposes double-stranded parallel −[Cd–OCO]– chains running along the a axis. These double-stranded 1D chains are supported by edge-fused six-membered [Cd2(COO)­O] units and extend to six others in the bc plane to form a 3D network (c).

elements.content: Compound D is a 3D network supported by 1D chains running along the a axis. Compound D also features a Cd2 L 2 macrocycle wherein a pair of chelating pyridine alcohol and carboxylates arrange in a head-to-tail fashion and resemble those found in A and B. The remaining two carboxylates of the macrocycle notably adopt a μ3-η1:η2 coordination mode, resembling that found in compound C. The μ3-η1:η2 coordinated carboxylate juxtaposes a double-stranded parallel −[Cd–OCO]– chain running along the a axis (a), which is also similar to the corresponding feature in C. This unique combination of the Cd2 L 2 macrocycle and μ3-η1:η2 coordination mode creates a double-stranded 1D chain with edge-fused four-membered Cd2O2 rings (similar to that in A) alternating with eight-membered [Cd2(COO)2] rings. Each of these double-stranded 1D chains extends to six equivalents to finally yield a 3D network (b).

elements.content: Compound A effectively converts to D upon heating and so we are keen to explore the intrinsic structural relationships between A and D. Within the Cd2 L 2 macrocycle of D, the two L ligands are arranged in the same head-to-tail fashion as that of A. Careful analysis revealed that the separation between the uncoordinated O atom from the monodentate carboxylate to the two Cd centers of the closest dimeric Cd2(H2O)2 unit was in the range of 4.020–4.487 Å, which is reasonable to form additional bonds upon water removal. We simulated such a link in A by replacing the water bridge (gray dashed line) with the Ocarboxylate bridge (orange dashed line) and obtained the exact same topology found in D (). As the shortest Cd···Cd separation along the a axis shrinks from 7.1422(11) Å in A to 6.6706(13) Å in D, the length of the b axis also shrinks significantly from 9.2320(14) Å in A to 7.6215(15) Å in D, but with little change in the c axis (12.1834(18) Å in A versus 12.097(2) Å in D) (Table S1). The net result is that the cell volume shrinks from 749.7(2) Å3 to 575.95(19) Å3 (a 23% volume decrease). On the other hand, the conversion of E to A is assumed to be a more complex, multistep intermolecular process (see Supporting Information for a detailed discussion).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Conversions

Compound A effectively converts to D upon heating and so we are keen to explore the intrinsic structural relationships between A and D. Within the Cd2 L 2 macrocycle of D, the two L ligands are arranged in the same head-to-tail fashion as that of A. Careful analysis revealed that the separation between the uncoordinated O atom from the monodentate carboxylate to the two Cd centers of the closest dimeric Cd2(H2O)2 unit was in the range of 4.020-4.487 Å, which is reasonable to form additional bonds upon water removal. We simulated such a link in A by replacing the water bridge (gray dashed line) with the Ocarboxylate bridge (orange dashed line) and obtained the exact same topology found in D (). As the shortest Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation along the a axis shrinks from 7.1422(11) Å in A to 6.6706(13) Å in D, the length of the b axis also shrinks significantly from 9.2320(14) Å in A to 7.6215(15) Å in D, but with little change in the c axis (12.1834(18) Å in A versus 12.097(2) Å in D) (Table S1). The net result is that the cell volume shrinks from 749.7(2) Å3 to 575.95(19) Å3 (a 23% volume decrease). On the other hand, the conversion of E to A is assumed to be a more complex, multistep intermolecular process (see Supporting Information for a detailed discussion).

elements.content: Compound A is stable in water, as indicated by a reproducible PXRD pattern after stirring A in water for 7 days (Figure S6). This observation, coupled with the strong photoluminescence of A, encouraged us to study its sensing behavior in aqueous media. We were particularly interested in testing its specificity for particular metal ions, which is important from an environmental perspective.
elements.clean_text:
Compound A as the Fluorescent Probe for Selective Detection of Fe3+ 

Compound A is stable in water, as indicated by a reproducible PXRD pattern after stirring A in water for 7 days (Figure S6). This observation, coupled with the strong photoluminescence of A, encouraged us to study its sensing behavior in aqueous media. We were particularly interested in testing its specificity for particular metal ions, which is important from an environmental perspective.

elements.content: To explore this potential application, we added various metal ions (K+, Na+, Ca2+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Al3+, Cr3+, Fe3+) to aqueous suspensions of A (2.4 × 10–3 mol·L–1). Only Fe3+ significantly quenched the luminescence of A (). The presence of Cu2+ also resulted in some quenching, but to a very limited extent. Other metal ions exerted a negligible influence on the emission intensity of A.

Only Fe3+ significantly quenched the luminescence of A (). The presence of Cu2+ also resulted in some quenching, but to a very limited extent. Other metal ions exerted a negligible influence on the emission intensity of A.

MOF A, therefore, is a promising luminescent sensor for the selective detection of Fe3+ ion. The luminescent intensity of A decreased with increasing concentration of Fe3+ ion (), and the detection limit was calculated to be 0.58 ppm (Figure S7).

elements.content: There are several possible mechanisms to explain this luminescence quenching, including guest-induced electron/energy transfer, rupture/distortion of the structure by (partial) metal ion replacement, and Lewis acid/base interactions. To investigate further, we soaked A in a concentrated Fe­(NO3)3 aqueous solution (10–2 mol·L–1) for 5 min followed by filtration and repeated rinsing with deionized water. Energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS, Figure S8) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Figure S9) of the treated sample indicated the presence of Fe3+. However, the PXRD pattern of the sample showed very good agreement with that of the simulated A (Figure S10), suggesting that the overall structure remained intact. This observation excludes the metal ion replacement hypothesis. As the structure of A is nonporous, a plausible explanation is that Fe3+ ions are absorbed via (but not limited to) interaction with the alcoholic oxygen on the particle surface, and it causes an intramolecular electron transfer that quenches the luminescence of A.
elements.clean_text:
Possible Mechanism for the Fluorescent Quenching of A by Fe3+ 

There are several possible mechanisms to explain this luminescence quenching, including guest-induced electron/energy transfer, rupture/distortion of the structure by (partial) metal ion replacement, and Lewis acid/base interactions. To investigate further, we soaked A in a concentrated Fe(NO3)3 aqueous solution (10-2 mol⋅L-1) for 5 min followed by filtration and repeated rinsing with deionized water. Energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS, Figure S8) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Figure S9) of the treated sample indicated the presence of Fe3+. However, the PXRD pattern of the sample showed very good agreement with that of the simulated A (Figure S10), suggesting that the overall structure remained intact. This observation excludes the metal ion replacement hypothesis. As the structure of A is nonporous, a plausible explanation is that Fe3+ ions are absorbed via (but not limited to) interaction with the alcoholic oxygen on the particle surface, and it causes an intramolecular electron transfer that quenches the luminescence of A.

elements.content: We subsequently added aqueous NaF solution (0.1 mol·L–1) to a suspension of Fe3+-treated A to convert any absorbed cation to [FeF6]3–. The emission intensity of A gradually increased although not to the original level (Figure S11). This strongly suggests that Fe3+ ions are absorbed onto the surface of the MOF particle, rather than replacing the central Cd2+, as conversion of ligand coordinated Fe3+ to [FeF6]3– would destroy the coordination polymer, releasing free L ligand and producing a different emission spectrum.
elements.clean_text: We subsequently added aqueous NaF solution (0.1 mol⋅L-1) to a suspension of Fe3+-treated A to convert any absorbed cation to [FeF6]3-. The emission intensity of A gradually increased although not to the original level (Figure S11). This strongly suggests that Fe3+ ions are absorbed onto the surface of the MOF particle, rather than replacing the central Cd2+, as conversion of ligand coordinated Fe3+ to [FeF6]3- would destroy the coordination polymer, releasing free L ligand and producing a different emission spectrum.

elements.content: The complexity and diversity of the MOFs reported herein are due to the inequivalence of the three functional groups of the ligand H2 L and the multiple coordination modes available to carboxylate. The coordinating solvates DMF and H2O are also essential to define the relative arrangements of the ligand and metal centers, and this was the primary inspiration for our study of the relationships between these hydrated and dehydrated MOFs. We assume that even greater structural complexity can be achieved when the alcoholic proton of H2 L is removed. In addition, the fluorescent A selectively detects Fe3+ by quenching of the photoluminescence, even in the presence of other cations. We are currently developing additional pyridine-alcohol carboxylate based MOFs for the detection of hazardous metal cations and anions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The complexity and diversity of the MOFs reported herein are due to the inequivalence of the three functional groups of the ligand H2 L and the multiple coordination modes available to carboxylate. The coordinating solvates DMF and H2O are also essential to define the relative arrangements of the ligand and metal centers, and this was the primary inspiration for our study of the relationships between these hydrated and dehydrated MOFs. We assume that even greater structural complexity can be achieved when the alcoholic proton of H2 L is removed. In addition, the fluorescent A selectively detects Fe3+ by quenching of the photoluminescence, even in the presence of other cations. We are currently developing additional pyridine-alcohol carboxylate based MOFs for the detection of hazardous metal cations and anions.

Method 1 (direct synthesis): Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (15.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) was mixed with H2 L (27 mg, 0.1 mmol) and DMF/H2O (5 mL/5 mL) in a 15 mL pressure tube. The reaction was heated to 120 °C in an oven for 72 h and cooled to room temperature over 48 h to give colorless block crystals. The formation of A was accompanied by the formation of [Cd­(L)­(DMF)0.5] (B) and [Cd­(L)] (C).

Synthesis of [Cd­(L)] (<bold>D</bold>)

A crystalline sample of A (from a mixture with B and C) was heated to 110 °C in an oven. The dehydrated crystalline solid of D was obtained after 5 h. The subsequent characterization data are based on the A (from E) to D conversions. Anal. Calcd (%) for C14H9CdNO5: C 43.83, H 2.36, N 3.65; found: C 44.04, H 2.53, N 3.58. IR (KBr disk): 3183 (m), 1613 (s), 1564 (s), 1444 (m), 1412 (s), 1350 (m), 1281 (m), 1067 (m), 1038 (s), 931 (w), 787 (m), 717­(m) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Cd­(L)­(DMF)] (<bold>E</bold>)

A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (15.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) and H2 L (27 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 10 mL of DMF was placed in a 15 mL pressure tube and heated to 120 °C for 72 h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature over 48 h to give colorless block crystals. Yield: 16 mg (70.1% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd (%) for C17H16CdN2O6: C 44.71, H 3.53, N 6.13; found: C 44.16, H 3.51, N 6.33. IR (KBr disk): 3078 (w), 2931 (m), 1648 (s), 1608 (m), 1556 (s), 1443 (m), 1038 (w), 921­(m), 854 (m), 778 (s), 731 (m), 680 (m) cm–1.
